Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of the lift and virtual mass force in gas-liquid flows with particle-resolved direct numerical simulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1438143

Many chemical manufacturing processes are carried out in bubble column reactors in which gas bubbles are dispersed throughout a liquid to perform chemical reactions. These reactors are designed to contain a large number of small bubbles to increase the contact area between the gas and liquid phases. The dynamics of gas-liquid flow inside these reactors and in similar multiphase processes is often described using mathematical models called two-fluid models. This project focuses on improving two-fluid models by explicitly taking into account the effects of interactions among the bubbles on certain terms in the models. The investigators will evaluate these critical terms by using computational simulations of bubble motions that account for interactions among bubbles and the development of bubble assemblies in flow. The improved two-fluid model will then be used in computational fluid dynamic simulations to compare with experimental data and help validate the model. The results of the project will be useful to design and optimize a broad array of manufacturing processes such as fermentation, wastewater treatment, algae growth, and antibiotic production.

The accuracy of volume averaged two-fluid models for gas-liquid flow depends on terms that estimate momentum transfer between gas and liquid phases. These terms include several forces such as drag, lift and virtual mass forces. These forces are usually evaluated for the case of an isolated bubble in the flow. This project will study the effects of assemblies of interacting bubbles in the flow on the lift and virtual mass forces, and will use the results to develop improved momentum exchange terms for two-fluid models. The forces will be determined by conducting particle-resolved direct numerical simulations of spherical buoyant particles, which are a surrogate for bubbles in the limit where bubble deformation can be neglected. The simulations will be used to develop expressions for the lift and virtual mass forces for use in the two-fluid equations. The improved two-fluid models will then be used in computational fluid dynamics simulations over a wide range of operating conditions for which experimental data are available to validate the newly developed terms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many chemical manufacturing processes are carried out in bubble column reactors in which gas bubbles are dispersed throughout a liquid to perform chemical reactions. These reactors are designed to contain a large number of small bubbles to increase the contact area between the gas and liquid phases.  The dynamics of gas-liquid flow inside these reactors and in similar multiphase processes is often described using mathematical models called two-fluid models, which describe the bubbles and the liquid as continuum media, to lower the computational time it takes to obtain the results of simulations. These models require to know how to accurately compute forces acting on the bubbles, in order to provide precise results.

In order to contribute to improving the accuracy of these two-fluid models, this project focused on improving two-fluid models by explicitly taking into account the effects of interactions among the bubbles on certain terms in the models, which describe the forces acting on the bubbles. In particular, the focus has been on two forces, the drag force, which acts in the direction of relative motion of the bubbles with respect to the liquid, and the added (or virtual) mass force, which is due to the fact that a bubble moving in a liquid carries with itself a certain mass of liquid.

The investigation of these forces is possible considering small systems with several bubble configurations, and directly resolving the flow around the bubbles. This technique, called particle-resolved direct numerical simulation (PR-DNS) requires a very fine subdivision of the space surrounding the bubble and also of the bubble surface to be able to accurately calculate the forces acting on each bubble. During the project, an implementation of the PR-DNS developed in the group of Co-PI Subramaniam and called PUReIBM was used and improved to be able to perform calculations with buoyant particles (bubbles were approximated with spherical buoyant particles, which is acceptable in the flow conditions considered in the project) with density lower than the surrounding fluid. This required the lubrication force, which is due to the presence of a thin layer of liquid between two buoyant particles when they approach contact. Additional modifications to the PUReIBM code were needed to properly manage collisions of buoyant particles, and to make the solution method robust for the simulation cases needed to collect data for the modeling effort of the force terms mentioned above.

The direct numerical simulations allowed to understand the role of density ration on the velocity of the buoyant particles, and to explain the reason of this effect. The motion of bubbles is affected by fluctuations, which can be correlated or uncorrelated. The first (correlated) are represented by the turbulent kinetic energy, the second by a quantity called granular energy. It was found that the granular temperature increases when the density ratio between particles and fluid decreases. This was explained by means of the added mass effect. However, an inconsistency was observed in the model, which led to conclude that other effects, such as the interaction between the particle wakes may need to be taken into account to formulate a physically valid model.

The results obtained from the PR-DNS for what concerns the drag force, computed accounting for the influence of neighbor particles, were used in a two-fluid model and validated against experiments, obtaining satisfactory agreement. The drag laws were implemented in the open-source toolkit for fluid dynamics OpenFOAM®, and were contributed to its official code repository to improve dissemination of the project results. While performing this investigation, it was observed that the traditional two-fluid model predicts regions with unphysically high gas concentrations, not observed in the experiments. This observation led to formulate an improved two-fluid model, which incorporates an additional force term which accounts for the effect of gradients of the bubble concentration on the drag force. The introduction of this term improved the prediction of the two-fluid model by removing the previously mentioned unphysical behavior.

The project provided training opportunities to five graduate students (2 M.Sc., 3 Ph.D.), three of which completed their studies and are currently employed in closely related engineering areas, where they are applying computational fluid dynamics to engineering problems. The other two Ph.D. students are successfully progressing in their studies towards graduation. Three additional graduate students contributed to reach the outcomes of the project and are continuing their studies under the guidance of the principal investigators.

Two journal articles were published on peer-reviewed journals as result of the work performed in this project, and one conference presentation was delivered at the Americal Physical Society Annual Meeting.
